The  Electric  Sales  and  Revenue  is  prepared  by  the Electric   Power   Division;   Office   of   Coal,   Nuclear, Electric   and   Alternate   Fuels;   Energy   Information Administration   (EIA);   U.S.   Department   of   Energy. Information  is  provided  on  electricity  sales,  associ- ated  revenue,  average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  sold, and   number   of   consumers   throughout   the   United States.  The  data  provided  in  the  Electric  Sales  and Revenue  are  presented  at  the  national,  Census  divi- sion, State, and electric utility levels. The information is  based  on  annual  data  reported  by  electric  utilities for the calendar year ending December 31, 2000.
Current   and   historical   publications   and   databases related  to  the  contents  of  Electric Sales and Revenue, 2000    are    also    available    on    the    EIA    website (http://www.eia.doe.gov/cneaf/
electricity/esr/esr_sum.html).
Target Audience
In  the  private  sector,  users  of  the  Electric  Sales  and Revenue  include  researchers,  analysts,  and  members of the electric power industry community. Other users include   financial   and   investment   institutions,   eco- nomic   development   organizations,   special   interest groups,  lobbyists,  electric  power  associations,  and  the news media.
In     the     public     sector,     users     include     analysts, researchers,    statisticians,    and    other    professionals engaged  in  regulatory,  policy,  and  program  activities for  Federal,  State,  and  local  governments.  Congress, other  legislative  bodies,  public  service  commissions, and  other  special  government  groups  also  use  infor- mation  on  general  trends  related  to  electricity  at  State and  national  levels.  Data  in  this  report  are  used  in analytical  studies  to  evaluate  new  legislation  and  reg- ulatory  alternatives  and  to  forecast  demand  for  elec- tric power.

Source of Data
Data  published  in  the  Electric  Sales  and  Revenue  are compiled    from    Form    EIA-861,    "Annual    Electric Utility  Report."  Form  EIA-861  is  an  annual  census  of electric  utilities,  including  retail  and  wholesale  power marketers,  in  the  United  States.  The  Form  EIA-861 also  collects  information  from  the  power  authorities of   the   Territories   of   American   Samoa,   Guam,   the Virgin  Islands,  and  the  Dominion  of  Puerto  Rico.  In 2000,  the  form  was  used  to  collect  information  on  the production,   sale   and   delivery   of   electricity   from approximately   3,300   electric   utility   respondents.   A detailed    description    of    the    form    is    included    in Appendix D, Technical Notes.
National  level  data  presented  in  Tables  1  through  13, the  charts  supporting  Table  1,  and  discussed  in  the text    include    the    50    States    and    the    District    of Columbia,   but   do   not   include   the   territories   and Puerto   Rico.   Data   for   these   power   authorities   are included  in  the  utility-level  data  displayed  in  Tables
14  through  17.  Data  in  Table  1  and  the  supporting charts  immediately  following  Table  1,  combine  sales, revenue  and  consumer  counts  for  both  "bundled"  and "unbundled"   consumers.   Unbundled   consumers   are those  provided  energy  and  delivery  services  by  sepa- rate  utility  entities.  Unbundled  consumers  were  pro- vided both services bundled by a single entity prior to deregulation.  Table  1,  and  the  supporting  charts,  also reflect  a  balancing-line  adjustment  for  underreporting in    the    States    of    California,    Massachusetts,    and Montana  in  all  consumer  sectors,  and  in  New  York  in all  consumer  sectors  except  the  residential  sector  (see the  Footnotes  for  Appendix  Tables  C1,  C2,  C3,  and C4,   and   the   accompanying   discussion   for   further explanation).  Tables  2  through  17  include  data  only for those bundled customers provided both energy and delivery service by a single utility entity. Appendix C, Tables  C1  through  C4,  present  data  only  for  "unbun- dled"  consumers  who  selected  alternate  energy  sup- pliers in deregulated markets, the energy sales and the associated  energy  revenue.  Appendix  Table  C5  (new) presents  the  State-level  revenue  received  by  distrib- ution utilities for delivery services provided to unbun- dled  consumers  who  selected  alternate  energy  service providers.   Therefore   delivery   revenue   in   Table   C5 should  be  combined  at  the  State  level  with  the  energy revenue    presented    in    Tables    C1    through    C4    to describe  the  full  costs  of  electric  service  for  unbun- dled customers.

Background
Electric  power  is  an  integral  part  of  life  in  the  United States.   It   is   indispensable   to   factories,   commercial establishments,   homes,   and   even   most   recreational facilities.   Lack   of   electric   power   causes   not   only inconvenience,  but  also  economic  loss  due  to  reduced industrial  production.  Electric  utilities  are  responsible for  ensuring  an  adequate  and  reliable  source  of  elec- tricity  to  all  consumers  in  their  service  territories  at  a reasonable   cost.   Regulatory   functions   are   divided between  Federal  (wholesale)  and  State  (retail)  author- ities.
State   public   service   commissions   have   jurisdiction primarily    over    the    large,    vertically    integrated, investor-owned  electric  utilities that  owned  more  than 60  percent  of  the  Nation's  generating  capacity  and  75 percent  of  its  transmission  capacity  and  served  about 73  percent  of  ultimate  consumers  in  2000.  There  are
240  investor-owned  electric  utilities,  2,009  publicly owned   electric   utilities,   894   consumer-owned   rural electric  cooperatives,  and  9  Federal  electric  utilities. Approximately  20  States  regulate  cooperatives,  and  7 States regulate municipal electric utilities; many State legislatures,   however,   defer   this   control   to   local municipal officials or cooperative members.
Consumer  Sectors.    Utility   service   territories   are geographically  distinct  from  one  another.  Each  terri- tory  is  usually  composed  of  many  different  types  of consumers.   Electricity   consumers   are   divided   into classes  of  service  or  sectors  (residential,  commercial, industrial, and other) based on the type of service they receive.
Sectorial  classification  of consumers  is  determined  by each  utility  and  is  based  on  various  criteria  such  as demand    levels,    rate    schedules,    North    American Industry  Classification  System  (NAICS)  codes,  dis- tribution  voltage,  accounting  methods,  end-use  appli- cations, and other social and economic characteristics. Electric utilities use consumer classifications for plan- ning  (e.g.,  load  growth  and  peak  demand)  and  for determining   their   sales   and   revenue   requirements (costs  of  service)  in  order  to  derive  their  rates.  Utili- ties  typically  employ  a  number  of  rate  schedules  for  a single  sector.  The  alternative  rate  schedules  reflect consumers'  varying  consumption  levels  and  patterns and the associated impact on the utility's costs of pro- viding electrical service.
Reclassification   of   consumers,   usually   between   the commercial  and  industrial  sectors,  may  occur  from year  to  year  due  to  changes  in  demand  level,  eco- nomic  factors,  or  other  factors.  For  this  reason,  the commercial  and  industrial  sectors  are  discussed  col-
column33:
lectively  as  the  nonresidential  sector  in  some  sections of this publication.
The residential sector includes private households and apartment buildings where energy is consumed prima- rily for space heating, water heating, air conditioning, lighting,  refrigeration,  cooking,  and  clothes  drying. The   commercial   sector   includes   nonmanufacturing business establishments such as hotels, motels, restau- rants,  wholesale  businesses,  retail  stores,  and  health, social,   and   educational   institutions.   Sometimes   the commercial sector includes small manufacturing facil- ities  as  well.  The  industrial  sector  includes  manufac- turing,  construction,  mining,  agriculture,  fishing,  and forestry   establishments   (NAICS   codes   11   through 3399).
An electric utility may classify commercial and indus- trial   consumers   based   on   either   NAICS   codes   or demand  and/or  usage  falling  within  specified  limits. The  limits  are  set  by  the  electric  utility  based  on  dif- ferent   rate   schedules.   The   “other”   sector   includes public  street  and  highway  lighting,  railroads  and  rail- ways,  municipalities,  divisions  or  agencies  of  State and  Federal  Governments  under  special  contracts  or agreements,  and  other  utility  departments,  as  defined by   the   pertinent   regulatory   agency   and/or   electric utility.
Revenue.     The   revenue   associated   with   sales   to bundled   ultimate   consumers   is   the   complete   retail sales   revenue   reported   by   the   utility.   Revenue   for these   bundled   consumers   includes   energy   charges, demand  charges,  consumer  service  charges,  environ- mental surcharges, fuel adjustments, and other miscel- laneous   charges.   The   revenue   shown   in   Tables   2 through  17  is  for  consumers  provided  full  service  by the  reporting  electric  utilities.  The  revenue  shown  in Table  1,  and  the  supporting  chart  for  revenue  and average   revenue   per   kilowatthour,   is   for   all   con- sumers,  bundled  and  unbundled,  within  the  State.  For information on "unbundled" customers served by com- petitive suppliers, see Appendix C.
Among    other    costs    of    service,    utility    operating revenues    include    State    and    local    taxes,    Federal income taxes, and other taxes paid by the utility. State and  local  authorities  tax  the  value  of  plants  (property taxes),  the  amount  of  revenues  (gross  receipts  taxes), purchases   of   materials   and   services   (sales   and   use taxes),  and  a  potentially  long  list  of  other  items  that vary extensively by taxing authority. Federal taxes are for the most part "payroll" taxes. Taxes deducted from employees'   pay,   such   as   Federal   income   taxes   and employees'  share  of  Social  Security  taxes  are  not  a part  of  the  utility's  "tax  costs,"  but  are  paid  to  the

taxing   authorities   in   the   name   of   the   employees. These  taxes  are  included  in  the  electric  utility's  costs of    service    (i.e.,    revenue    requirements)    and    are included  in  the  amounts  recovered  from  consumers  in rates   and   reported   in   operating   revenues.   Taxing authorities differ on whether a specific tax is assessed to  the  utility  or  to  the  consumer,  a  difference  that  in turn  determines  whether  or  not  the  tax  is  included  in the electric utility's operating revenues.
Average   Revenue   per   Kilowatthour.     Average revenue  per  kilowatthour  is  the  proxy  for  price  of electricity  to  the  ultimate  consumer.  Average  revenue per  kilowatthour  is  defined  as  the  cost  per  unit  of electricity  sold  and  is  calculated  by  dividing  retail electric  revenue  by  the  corresponding  sales  of  elec- tricity. The average revenue per kilowatthour is calcu- lated    for    all    consumers    and    for    each    sector (residential,  commercial,  industrial,  and  other).  The average revenue per kilowatthour reported in this pub- lication  in  Tables  2  through  17  represents  a  weighted average  of  consumer  revenue  and  sales  within  each sector  and  across  sectors  for  consumers  fully  served by  one  electric  utility.  Table  1  and  the  supporting charts   combine   both   bundled   and   unbundled   con- sumers.  For  information  on  consumers  served  in  com- petitive     markets     by     alternative     suppliers,     see Appendix C.
Average   revenue   per   kilowatthour   is   affected   by changes in the rate schedules used by the electric util- ities and by changes in the volume of electricity sales. Because  fixed  charges  remain  constant  regardless  of the volume of sales, average revenue per kilowatthour decreases  as  the  volume  of  sales  increases.  A  change in  average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  may  occur  when the  volume  of  electricity  sales  changes  (because  of  an increase/decrease   in   the   use   of   electricity   by   indi- vidual   consumers   or   an   increase/decrease   in   the number  of  ultimate  consumers)  across  all  sectors  or within  a  specific  sector.  Generally,  the  rate  schedules used  by  electric  utilities  are  designed  so  that  as  the volume  of  sales  increases,  the  revenue  increases  at  a slower    rate,    lowering    the    average    revenue    per kilowatthour.  The  net  effect  of  these  factors  on  the average   revenue   per   kilowatthour   presented   in   this publication has not been determined. Average revenue per  kilowatthour  is  affected  by  class  of  utility  owner- ship  and  by  class  of  service  (sector).  Consequently, data are presented in this publication by class of own- ership and sector.
Classes of Ownership.   The  electric  utility  industry in the United States includes approximately 3,150 tra- ditional  investor-owned,  publicly  owned,  cooperative, and  Federal  electric  utilities.  Historically,  investor- owned  electric  utilities  have  been  most  successful  in serving  large,  consolidated  markets  where  economies of  scale  afford  the  lowest  prices.  However,  publicly owned,  cooperative,  and  Federal  electric  utilities  all have  a  role  in  producing,  transmitting,  and  distrib- uting electricity.
Investor-owned  electric  utilities  are  privately  owned entities.  They  represent  8  percent  of  the  total  number of  electric  utilities  and  more  than  60  percent  of  tradi- tional   electric   utility   generating   capability,   gener-
column33:
ation, sales, and revenue in the United States. Like all private   businesses,   investor-owned   electric   utilities have  the  fundamental  objective  of  producing  a  return for   their   investors.   These   utilities   either   distribute profits  to  stockholders  as  dividends  or  reinvest  the profits.  Investor-owned  electric  utilities  are  granted service  monopolies  in  certain  geographic  areas  and are   obliged   to   serve   all   consumers.   As   franchised monopolies,  these  utilities  are  regulated  and  required to   charge   reasonable   prices,   to   charge   comparable prices  to  similar  classifications  of  consumers,  and  to give  consumers  access  to  services  under  similar  con- ditions.   Most   investor-owned   electric   utilities   are operating  companies  that  provide  basic  services  for the  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution  of  elec- tricity.    The    majority    of    investor-owned    utilities perform  all  three  functions.  They  operate  in  all  States except  Nebraska,  where  electric  utilities  consist  pri- marily  of  municipal  systems  and  public  power  dis- tricts.
Publicly  owned  electric  utilities  are  nonprofit  local government  agencies  established  to  provide  service  to their   communities   and   nearby   consumers   at   cost, returning  excess  funds  to  consumers  in  the  form  of community   contributions,   increased   economies   and efficiencies  in  operations,  and  reduced  rates.  Publicly owned   electric   utilities   include   municipals,   public power  districts,  State  authorities,  irrigation  districts, and other State organizations. Most municipal electric utilities  simply  distribute  power,  although  some  large ones  produce  and  transmit  electricity  as  well.  There are  approximately  2,000  publicly  owned  electric  utili- ties  in  the  United  States.  They  represent  about  64 percent   of   the   number   of   electric   utilities,   supply approximately   10   percent   of   generation   and   gener- ating  capability,  and  account  for  about  16  percent  of retail  sales  and  15  percent  of  revenue.  They  obtain their  financing  from  municipal  treasuries  and  from revenue  bonds  secured  by  proceeds  from  the  sale  of electricity.   Public   power   districts   and   projects   are concentrated    in    Nebraska,    Washington,    Oregon, Arizona, and California. Voters in a public utility dis- trict  elect  commissioners  or  directors  to  govern  the district   independent   of   any   municipal   government. State authorities, like the Power Authority of the State of  New  York  or  the  South  Carolina  Public  Service Authority,  are  agencies  of  their  respective  State  gov- ernments.  Irrigation  districts  may  have  other  forms  of organization.  In  the  Salt  River  Project  in  Arizona,  for example,  votes  for  the  board  of  directors  are  appor- tioned according to the size of landholdings.
Cooperative   electric   utilities   are   owned   by   their members   and   established   to   provide   electricity   to those members. These electric utilities operate in rural areas  with  low  concentrations  of  consumers  because these  areas  historically  have  been  viewed  as  uneco- nomical  operations  for  investor-owned  utilities.  There are  almost  900  cooperatives  operating  in  47  States; none operate in Connecticut, Hawaii, Rhode Island, or the District of Columbia. Cooperative electric utilities represent  about  28  percent  of  U.S.  electric  utilities, approximately  9  percent  of  sales  and  revenue,  and around  9  percent  of  generation  and  generating  capa- bility.  Cooperatives  are  incorporated  under  State  laws and  are  usually  directed  by  an  elected  board  of  direc-

tors, which in turn selects a manager. The Rural Utili- ties    Service    (formerly    the    Rural    Electrification Administration),  the  National  Rural  Utilities  Cooper- ative   Finance   Corporation,   the   Federal   Financing Bank,  and  the  Bank  for  Cooperatives  are  important sources of debt financing for cooperatives.
The 9 Federal electric utilities in the United States are part  of  several  agencies  in  the  U.S.  Government:  the Army   Corps   of   Engineers   in   the   Department   of Defense,  the  Bureau  of  Indian  Affairs  and  the  Bureau of  Reclamation  in  the  Department  of  the  Interior,  the International  Boundary  and  Water  Commission  in  the Department  of  State,  the  Power  Marketing  Adminis- trations   in   the   Department   of   Energy   (Bonneville, Southeastern,  Southwestern,  and  Western  Area),  and the  Tennessee  Valley  Authority.  Three  Federal  agen- cies     operate     Federal     generating     facilities:     the Tennessee  Valley  Authority,  the  largest  Federal  pro- ducer;  the  U.S.  Army  Corps  of  Engineers;  and  the
U.S.  Bureau  of  Reclamation.  The  Tennessee  Valley Authority  markets  its  own  power  while  generation  by the  U.S.  Army  Corps  of  Engineers  (except  for  the North   Central   Division,   i.e.,   Saint   Mary's   Falls   at Sault  Ste.  Marie,  Michigan)  and  the  U.S.  Bureau  of Reclamation  is  marketed  by  the  Federal  power  mar- keting    administrations:    Bonneville,    Southeastern, Southwestern,   and   Western   Area.   The   four   power marketing   administrations   also   purchase   energy   for resale  from  other  electric  utilities  in  the  United  States and Canada.
Federal  electric  utilities  represent  less  than  1  percent of   all   electric   utilities,   provide   approximately   10 percent  of  all  generating  capability  and  generation, and  account  for  1.5  percent  of  total  sales  to  ultimate consumers  and  about  0.6  percent  of  the  associated revenue.  Federal  electric  utility  generation  is  prima- rily  sold  for  resale  to  municipal  and  cooperative  elec- tric    utilities    and    to    other    nonprofit    preference consumers,  as  required  by  law.  Federal  power  is  sold not  for  profit,  but  to  recover  the  costs  of  operations. Federal   electric   utilities   operate   approximately   180 power  plants.  Most  of  the  power  plants  are  Federal hydroelectric   projects   initially   designed   for   flood control and irrigation purposes.
Current Issues in the Electric Power Industry
The  electric  power  industry  is  evolving  from  a  highly regulated,   monopolistic   industry   with   traditionally structured electric utilities to a less regulated, compet- itive  industry.  The  Public  Utility  Regulatory  Policies Act  of  1978  opened  up  competition  in  the  generation market  with  the  creation  of  qualifying  facilities.  The Energy  Policy  Act  of  1992  (EPACT)  removed  some constraints  on  ownership  of  electric  generation  facili- ties   and   encouraged   increased   competition   in   the wholesale electric power business.
The  EPACT  amended  the  Federal  Power  Act  (FPA) such  that  any  electric  utility  can  apply  to  the  Federal Energy  Regulatory  Commission  (FERC)  for  an  order requiring   another   electric   utility   to   provide   trans-
column33:
mission   service   (wheeling).   Prior   to   EPACT,   the FERC   could   not   mandate   that   an   electric   utility provide wheeling services for wholesale electric trade. This change in the law permits owners of electric gen- erating  equipment  to  sell  wholesale  power  (sales  for resale) to noncontiguous utilities.
Many  State  legislatures  and  the  Congress  are  consid- ering  legislation  that  will  allow  competition  in  retail sales   of   electric   power.   In   1996,   Rhode   Island, Pennsylvania, and California passed bills that allowed end-use  customers  in  their  States  to  choose  among competitive  generation  suppliers.  The  plans  phased  in retail choice for some consumers as early as 1998, and for  all  consumers  by  2001.  Transmission  and  distrib- ution  will  remain  regulated  functions  with  rules  to assure  open  access  to  lines  for  all  competitors.  Pilot programs  for  retail  wheeling  were  underway  in  New Hampshire   and   at   major   utilities   in   several   States. This interest in retail competition points to an increas- ingly  competitive  electric  power  industry.  Presently, most  electric  rates  are  based  on  embedded  historical costs.  Future  electric  rates  are  likely  to  be  dynamic, reflecting  the  current  cost  of  providing  service.  In  a competitive    environment,    unbundling    of    electric power  services  and  pricing  that  reflects  time-of-day and seasonal variations will become more common.
Continuing   deregulation   at   both   Federal   and   State levels   is   transforming   the   historically   monopolistic electric   power   industry   into   an   industry   that   will eventually  increase  competition  in  the  generation  and service   components   of   the   electric   power   industry, and  change  the  nature  of  the  way  electricity  is  priced, traded, and marketed in the United States.
Data Collection and Presentation Issues
For   more   than   15   years,   the   Energy   Information Administration  (EIA)  has  collected  information  from electric  utility  respondents  on,  among  other  things, retail   electricity   sales,   the   associated   revenue,   and consumer  (meter)  counts  in  full-service,  noncompet- itive  markets.  In  more  recent  years,  the  EIA  collected power sales and the energy-only charge of the custom- er's  bill  from  deregulated  "Energy  Service  Providers" (ESPs)  for  consumers  who  switched  their  energy  sup- plier  in  restructured  markets.  For  the  first  time,  for the   year   2000   cycle,   the   EIA   has   collected   the delivery-revenue  component  of  the  customer's  bill  for those  consumers  who  switched  suppliers.  It  is  now possible  to  combine  utility  bundled,  utility  unbundled delivery-only   revenue,   and   ESP   unbundled   power sales  and  related  revenues  at  the  State  level  to  deter- mine  the  composite  average  revenue  per  kilowatthour for virtually all retail electricity consumers in a State.

For  instance,  most  traditional  utility  respondents have  reported  data  to  the  EIA  or  predecessor  agencies for  decades,  and  on  the  Form  EIA-861  for  17  years. These  respondents  have  evolved  accounting  and  other information  management  systems  over  the  years  that have  enabled  them  to  provide  high-quality  data  to  the EIA.  However,  new  industry  participants,  especially retail   ESPs   first   appearing   in   the   mid-'90s,   have shown   an   organizational   volatility   with   regard   to market  entry,  affiliate  creation,  and  market  departure. Many  of  these  recent  industry  participants  have  had limited   opportunity   to   develop   data   tracking   and reporting systems similar to those of the long-standing traditional energy suppliers.
Users  of  the  information  in  this  publication  should also  be  aware  that  customer  sector  definitional  differ- ences  for  the  megawatthours  and  revenue  reported  by competitive     ESPs     selling     power,     and     utilities reporting  the  related  delivery  services,  will  result  in some minor variance from that which would be shown were   all   respondents   using   consistent   criteria   for sector classifications.
Information   provided   by   respondents,   particularly with  regard  to  delivery-service  revenue,  was  difficult for  utilities  to  isolate  for  reporting  to  the  EIA.  Many challenges  presented  themselves  to  administrative  and billing staff at affected utilities. For instance, in some States  with  "retail  wheeling"  programs,  large  indus- trial  customers  could  select  one  alternate  supplier  for part   of   their   load,   another   alternate   supplier   for another   portion,   and   the   regulated   utility   for   the balance.  Also,  the  ratios  of  energy  provided  by  mul- tiple   suppliers   could   fluctuate   during   the   reporting year.
Moreover,    accounting    and    other    general    ledger systems  used  to  track  customer  counts,  consumption, and   related   revenue   receipts,   by   type   (competitive supplier  or  traditional  supplier)  have  not  been  fully implemented   by   respondents   as   markets   open.   In recognition    of    the    difficulties    in    reporting    the requested data, most respondents added layers of data- review    involving    other    departments    within    their organization   before   certifying   the   information   pro- vided.  Nonetheless,  for  reasons  discussed  above,  data shown  here  impacted  by  competitive  market  customer migrations,  were  often  characterized  by  respondents as "reliable estimates."
Customers   choose   alternate   suppliers   because   they gain    savings    over    their    traditional    utility's    rate. However,   other   customers   remain   with   their   tradi- tional  supplier  because  ESPs  cannot  beat  every  price offered  by  the  traditional  utility.  Statistical  data  gen- erated  by  the  electricity  consumption  and  billings,  for customers  who  did  not  choose  an  alternate  supplier, are  recorded  by  the  local  utility  and  submitted  to  the EIA.   Statistical   data   generated   by   "shopping"   cus- tomers  are  recorded  by  the  ESP  and  submitted  to  the EIA.    For    the    "shopping"    customers,    the    related delivery  services  revenue  are  submitted  to  the  EIA  by the    distribution    company    for    customers    in    their
column33:
service   area   regardless   of   the   ESP   providing   the power. Because a customer at the high end of rates for electric  power  would  naturally  be  more  inclined  to switch  suppliers,  and  customers  at  the  low  end  would be  more  likely  to  remain  with  their  traditional  sup- plier,  a  distillation  process  may  sometimes  result  in the  traditional  utility  retaining  a  slightly  higher  ratio of low-rate consumers, than competing ESPs.
It should also be noted that specific data on individual customers'  level  of  service  (i.e.,  higher  cost  "green" power,  versus  fossil-fuel,  or  firm  versus  interruptible) or  load  characteristics  (demand  and  energy  consump- tion  patterns)  are  not  collected.  Also,  data  are  State- level  and  utility-level  averages  and  do  not  address whether  specific  customers,  in  specific  utility  service territories, paid more, or less than the State average.
Average Monthly Bill.   For residential consumers, as shown  in  Table  1,  average  monthly  consumption  is related  to  the  average  cost  per  kilowatthour  to  the consumer. For instance, of the nine contiguous Census Divisions,   the   Middle   Atlantic   Division   has   the highest  average  cost  to  consumers  per  kilowatthour,
11.39   cents;   however,   it   has   the   second   lowest average   monthly   consumption,   633   kilowatthours, with  an  average  monthly  bill  of  $72.06. $78.31.   The   difference   between   residential   average monthly   bills   for   these   divisions,   each   at   opposite extremes  of  cost  and  usage,  is  $6.25  per  month.  The findings  reflect  consumer  adaptability  to  the  cost  of  a product or service.
Looking   at   State-level   data,   the   Pacific   Division further   illustrates   that   consumers   seek   alternatives when   faced   with   high   prices   for   electric   power. Year in Review, 2000
In  2000,  full-service  sales  of  electricity  to  "bundled" ultimate     consumers     increased     to     3,310     billion kilowatthours.1   Total  revenue  from  sales  of  electricity to   ultimate   consumers   increased   4.1   percent,   from
$215  billion  in  1999  to  $224  billion  in  2000.  The average revenue per kilowatthour of electricity sold to ultimate  consumers  in  the  United  States  in  2000  was
6.78  cents,  an  increase  from  the  1999  level  of  6.66 cents.
Sales  by  Sector.    Sales  to  the  residential  sector  in 2000  increased  3.7  percent  from  the  1999  level,  to 1,183  billion  kWh,  which  represented  35.7  percent  of sales    to    ultimate    consumers.    The    nonresidential sectors2    (i.e.,  the  commercial  and  industrial  sectors) increased  1.5  percent  over  the  1999  level,  to  2,019 billion  kWh,  which  represented  61  percent  of  sales  to ultimate  consumers.  Sales  to  the  “other”  sector  were 108 billion kWh in 2000.
Revenue   by   Sector.     For   the   residential   sector, revenue  increased  to  $97  billion  in  2000  and  repres- ented  43.3  percent  of  the  total  revenue  from  sales  to ultimate  consumers.  Revenue  for  the  nonresidential sectors increased by 4 percent, to $120 billion in 2000 and  represented  53.6  percent  of  total  revenue  from sales  to  ultimate  consumers.  Revenue  for  the  “other” sector remained at $7 billion in 2000.
Average  Revenue  per  Kilowatthour  by  Sector. For    the    residential    sector,    average    revenue    per kilowatthour increased 0.6 percent, from 8.16 cents in 1999  to  8.21  cents  in  2000.  For  the  nonresidential sectors,  average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  increased
2.6  percent,  from  5.81  cents  in  1999  to  5.96  cents  in 2000. Average revenue for the “other” sector was 6.48 cents in 2000.

Cost of Electricity
The  process  of  determining  the  costs  of  electricity usually  occurs  in  three  stages:  (1)  revenue  require- ments  are  determined,  (2)  revenue  requirements  are allocated  to  different  sectors,  and  (3)  rate  schedules for each sector are established.
Revenue Requirements.   Revenue  requirements  are set to reimburse the electric utility for providing elec- tric  service.  They  reflect  the  anticipated  costs  of  pro- viding  services  for  some  period  of  time  in  the  future, usually  a  year.  Revenue  requirements  include  invest- ment   depreciation;   expenses   for   production,   trans- mission,    and    distribution    systems;    sales    costs; consumer costs; Federal and other taxes; and adminis- tration  and  general  expenses.  Revenue  requirements also  include  an  allowance  for  profit  in  the  case  of investor-owned electric utilities.
Allocation  of  Revenue.    Allocation  of  revenue  to each  sector  is  guided  by  the  costs  of  service  to  each sector and the type of consumers served in the sectors. For  example,  the  costs  of  service  to  the  residential sector  are  higher  than  the  costs  to  the  commercial  or industrial   sectors   because   of   residential   consumers' relatively  low  consumption  levels,  the  large  number of  residential  consumers,  and  the  extensive  distrib- ution  lines  needed  to  provide  service.  The  economic activity  or  type  of  business  of  ultimate  consumers  is not  necessarily  the  criteria  used  by  electric  utilities  to classify  consumers,  determine  revenue  requirements, and   set   rates.   Electric   utilities,   in   many   instances, determine revenue requirements and set rates based on consumers'  level  of  demand  and/or  consumption  of electricity.
The  residential  sector  represents  87.7  percent  of  ulti- mate consumers and accounts for 35.7 percent of sales to  ultimate  consumers  and  43.3  percent  of  associated revenue. The commercial sector provides 11.2 percent of  the  consumers  and  accounts  for  30.2  percent  of sales   and   32.9   percent   of   revenue.   The   industrial sector  represents  0.4  percent  of  ultimate  consumers,
column33:
accounts for 30.8 percent of sales, and 20.7 percent of revenue.  The  remaining  sales  are  made  to  the  “other” sector,   which   includes   public   street   and   highway lighting,  railroads  and  railways,  municipalities,  divi- sions  or  agencies  of  State  and  Federal  Governments under   special   contracts   or   agreements,   and   other utility departments, as defined by the pertinent regula- tory agency and/or electric utility.
Rate Schedules.   Rate schedules for electric utilities are  designed  to  reimburse  utilities  for  operation,  gen- eration,  maintenance,  rental  fees  for  equipment,  and demand  and  energy  charges.  Operation,  generation, maintenance,    and    rental    fees    for    equipment    are usually  fixed  charges  that  are  assessed  monthly  or annually.  Demand  charges  are  often  fixed,  but  can vary   with   the   peak   demand   of   the   utility.   Energy charges  vary  according  to  the  amount  of  electricity delivered.
Rate   schedules   developed   by   electric   utilities   are unique  to  each  utility.  Rate  schedules  reflect  various considerations   that   are   important   to   the   economic welfare  of  the  electric  utility  and  may  reflect  other considerations  as  well,  for  example,  residential  rates that  may  provide  economical  service  to  low-income families.  Generally,  commercial  or  industrial  billings are determined by the levels of demand and consump- tion  of  electricity  rather  than  by  consumers'  economic activity. For example, a light manufacturing establish- ment   with   a   manufacturing   process   that   consumes little   energy   may   be   billed   at   a   commercial   rate because  its  consumption  is  not  high  enough  to  qualify for  the  industrial  schedule.  Conversely,  a  large  com- mercial  building  may  have  sufficient  consumption  to be billed at an industrial rate.
Authority for approval of rate schedules is determined by  the  class  of  electric  utility  ownership.  Investor- owned  electric  utilities  are  regulated  by  State  public service  commissions  and  the  Federal  Energy  Regula- tory   Commission.   Publicly   owned   and   cooperative electric  utilities  in  most  States  are  regulated  by  their consumer-owners through locally elected or appointed officials.  A  detailed  discussion  of  utility  classes  of ownership  is  contained  in  the  "Overview"  section  of this publication.

This   chapter   presents   background   information   on average   revenue   per   kilowatthour   at   the   national, Census division, State, and electric utility levels.
Average Revenue per Kilowatthour at the National, Census Division, and
State Levels
Average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  by  sector  and  State is  calculated  by  dividing  revenue  from  sales  to  ulti- mate consumers in a given sector and State by the cor- responding   sales   for   that   sector   and   State.   The resulting    statistic    is    the    average    revenue    per kilowatthour   sold   by   consumer   sector.   Many   rate schedules  have  a  minimum  service  charge,  and  most set  a  declining  rate  per  unit  of  consumption  as  con- sumption  increases.  Rate  schedules  for  the  commer- cial   and   industrial   sectors   almost   always   have   a demand charge in addition to an energy charge. These charges lower the average revenue per kilowatthour as consumption increases.
Average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  for  the  residential sector  is  usually  higher  than  for  other  sectors,  due  to the  relatively  small  amount  of  consumption  per  con- sumer  and  the  relatively  low  load  factor.  Load  factor is  average  load  expressed  as  a  percentage  of  peak load.  Consumers  with  a  small  amount  of  consumption and  low  load  factors  are  more  costly  to  serve  per  unit of  energy  than  consumers  with  large  amounts  of  con- sumption   and   high   load   factors.   Residential   con- sumers  typically  have  low  load  factors  compared  with industrial or commercial consumers.
Average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  for  the  residential sector  increased  each  year  from  1993  through  1995, declined   in   1996,   increased   again   in   1997,   and decreased   in   1998   and   1999.   For   2000,   average revenue  increased  to  8.21  cents  per  kilowatthour.  For the first time in 6 years, the commercial and industrial sectors  showed  an  increase  in  average  revenue  per kilowatthour;   commercial   increased   0.10   cents   and industrial increased 0.14 cents from 1999.
Average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  for  investor-owned electric  utilities  increased  from  6.83  cents  in  1999  to
6.95  cents  in  2000;  publicly  owned  electric  utilities increased  from  6.30  cents  in  1999  to  6.40  cents  in 2000;  and  cooperative  electric  utilities  increased  from
6.65  in  1999  to  6.70  cents  in  2000.  Investor-owned electric  utilities  continue  to  have  the  highest  average
column33:
revenue   per   kilowatthour,   surpassing   cooperatives again    for    the    tenth    year.    Average    revenue    per kilowatthour   for   Federal   electric   utilities   increased from 2.45 cents in 1999 to 2.53 cents in 2000.
Federal   electric   utilities   have   the   lowest   average revenue   per   kilowatthour   among   ownership   classes because  these  electric  utilities  have  access  to  rela- tively  low-cost  financing  and  generally  utilize  inex- pensive    hydroelectric    facilities.    Because    publicly owned  electric  utilities  also  have  access  to  relatively low-cost   financing   and   are   nonprofit   entities,   they have   lower   average   revenue   per   kilowatthour   than investor-owned   electric   utilities.   Although   cooper- ative   electric   utilities   have   economic   advantages similar  to  those  of  publicly  owned  electric  utilities, cooperatives  generally  serve  sparsely  populated  areas and  provide  service  to  a  higher  percentage  of  rural residential  consumers  than  other  classes  of  utilities. Additionally, many cooperatives do not generate elec- tricity,  but  as  full  requirement  customers  of  electric utilities  with  generation  facilities,  must  pay  require- ment demand charges. As a result, cooperative electric utilities   usually   have   higher   average   revenue   per kilowatthour than publicly owned electric utilities.
Because  of  the  type  and  availability  of  capacity  and the   cost   of   fuel,   average   revenue   per   kilowatthour differs   across   U.S.   Census   divisions.   Petroleum   is generally  a  more  expensive  energy  source  than  coal and natural gas. Because the New England and Middle Atlantic Census Divisions rely primarily on petroleum to  fuel  their  generation,  they  tend  to  have  an  average revenue   per   kilowatthour   that   exceeds   the   national average.  The  East  and  West  South  Central  Divisions rely   on   gas-fired   generation   and   the   East   North Central  and  South  Atlantic  Census  Divisions  rely  on coal-fired  generation.  Because  the  Mountain  Census Division   relies   on   inexpensive   hydroelectric   gener- ation,  average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  in  this  region is usually below the national average for all classes of consumers.    The    Census    divisions    where    Federal hydroelectric  facilities  provide  significant  amounts  of electricity,   such   as   the   East   South   Central   Census Division,    also    have    low    average    revenue    per kilowatthour.3

Average Revenue per Kilowatthour at the Electric Utility Level
Average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  of  electricity  sold for each utility is calculated by dividing revenue from sales  to  ultimate  consumers  of  the  electric  utility  by the  corresponding  electricity  sales  to  all  sectors  by that  utility.  Average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  is  a function     of     consumer     base,     ownership     class, geographic  location,  cost  of  fuel,  financing  arrange- ments, and other factors.
The   average   revenue   per   kilowatthour   varies   by sector;  accordingly,  differences  between  utilities  may represent  differences  in  the  proportion  of  sales  to  dif- ferent sectors. Average revenue per kilowatthour for a given   utility   does   not   reflect   differences   that   may exist in its revenue structure across sectors.
Average   revenue   per   kilowatthour   to   ultimate   con- sumers for Federally owned utilities tends to be lower than  for  the  other  ownership  classes.  Among  several factors contributing to this is that Federal electric util- ities   are   primarily   wholesale   power   producers   and serve  few,  if  any,  residential  consumers.  They  also have   access   to   relatively   inexpensive   hydropower. Publicly  owned  and  cooperative  utilities  share  some advantages  that  can  result  in  lower  average  revenue per  kilowatthour  than  investor-owned  utilities:  they are  nonprofit,  have  access  to  low-cost  financing,  and have   preference   for   purchasing   Federal   wholesale power.  However,  cooperatives  generally  have  broad service areas and a high percentage of residential con- sumers because of the nature of the rural communities that  they  traditionally  serve.  Municipal  utilities  have more   consolidated   service   areas   and   likely   have   a broader  base  of  industrial  and  commercial  consumers that  cooperatives.  The  result  is  that  cooperatives  have a  higher  cost  of  service  than  municipal  utilities  and  a corresponding       higher       average       revenue       per kilowatthour.  Investor-owned  utilities  must  produce  a rate-of-return  for  their  investors  and  generally  have diverse   consumer   bases   and   utilize   various   fuels. Average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  for  individual  utili- ties   usually   ranges   between   4   and   12   cents   per kilowatthour.
In  Alaska,  average  revenue  per  kilowatthour  reflects the  high  costs  of  service  associated  with  generation and  distribution  in  that  State.  Utilities  in  Alaska  typi- cally  consist  of  isolated  systems,  which  lack  an  inte-
column33:
grated   transmission   system   and   the   advantages   of economy of scale. All 73 of the reporting electric util- ities     in     Alaska     have     average     revenues     per kilowatthour  exceeding  the  U.S.  average.  The  Power Cost   Equalization   (PCE)   subsidy   by   the   State   of Alaska was designed to compensate consumers served by  electric  utilities  located  in  rural  areas  where  trans- mission   access   is   limited   and   electric   power   is produced   with   expensive   diesel   gas   turbines.   The subsidy  is  allocated  to  electric  utilities  based  on  con- sumer   sector   and   demand   for   electricity   in   each sector.   Electric   utilities   that   qualify   for   the   PCE program  are  required  to  notify  consumers  of  the  cost of  electric  service  and  the  cost  minus  the  State  equal- ization.  Consumers  receiving  the  subsidy  do  not  actu- ally pay the high rates. The PCE subsidy has not been subtracted   from   the   total   revenue   of   those   electric utilities  receiving  compensation  for  high  energy  costs in Tables 14 through 17 in this publication.
Electric  utilities  operating  on  islands  with  high  sea- sonal   populations   also   tend   to   have   high   average revenue  per  kilowatthour.  High  demand  charges  are needed  to  recover  the  fixed  equipment  and  operating costs  associated  with  generating  electricity  at  infre- quent  times.  These  circumstances  pertain  to  only  a few  utilities,  located  primarily  on  the  East  Coast  and in the Great Lakes area.

Provisions  of  the  Energy Policy Act of 1992 (EPACT) authorized  the  Federal  Energy  Regulatory  Commis- sion  (FERC)  to  require  open  access  to  the  privately- owned    electric    transmission    systems    under    its jurisdiction   much   as   the   Federal   Communications Commission    and    telecommunications    deregulation expanded    customer    access    to    the    nation's    long- distance  communications  lines.  The  EPACT  allowed each  State  to  determine  the  level  of  retail  competition within   its   borders,   and,   for   the   first   time,   enabled organizations    not    previously    engaged    in    electric power  transactions,  to  purchase,  transmit  and  resell electric    power    across    traditional    electric    utility borders. Those organizations are usually referred to as power marketers.
Power marketers, like traditional electric utilities, buy and  sell  electric  power  in  the  wholesale  market.  But power  marketers  differ  from  traditional  electric  utili- ties  in  both  their  lack  of  ownership  interest  in  gener- ation,  transmission  and  distribution  facilities,  and  in the    geographic    sweep    of    their    transactions.    For instance,     in     1995     Electric     Clearinghouse,     Inc. ((Dynegy    Marketing)    a    FERC    registered    power marketer)  purchased  power  at  off-peak  rates  from  the California  Department  of  Water  Resources  generated during   the   early   morning   hours,   scheduled   trans- mission  service  through  several  major  systems  and control   areas,   and   delivered   the   power   across   the country  to  the  Jacksonville  (FL)  Electric  Authority. Owing to the three hour time-zone difference, Electric Clearinghouse  was  able  to  sell  the  power  at  on-peak rates in Florida. Electric Clearinghouse neither owned nor  operated  any  of  the  generation  and  transmission facilities used in completing the transaction.
Some  power  marketers  are  affiliated  with  companies owning  reserves  of  other  sources  of  energy,  such  as natural gas. An exchange of fuel for electricity known as  “tolling”  allows  a  power  marketer  with  access  to fuel  resources  to  “rent”  a  generator  from  an  electric utility,  supply  fuel  to  the  unit  to  produce  electricity, pay  the  “rental”  fee  with  a  portion  of  the  generated power,  and  take  delivery  of  the  balance  for  sale  to customers.
The   number   of   registered   power   marketers   with wholesale rates approved by the FERC has grown sub- stantially  in  the  past  few  years  from  11  in  1994  to approximately  500  in  2000  of  which  about  120  are affiliated  with  traditional  electric  utilities.  However, fewer than half of those registered with FERC in 2000 actually  conducted  wholesale  transactions.  Moreover,
column33:
many  registered  power  marketers  undertook  few  pur- chases and sales wishing to simply test techniques and procedures,  and  observe  marketplace  opportunities.  In 2000,   power   marketers   purchased   and   sold   in   the wholesale  market  over  3  billion  megawatthours  -  an increase  over  1999  activities.  Most  power  marketers make   their   impact   by   numerous   small   transactions with  sales  to  many  customers.  In  fact,  many  power marketer  transactions  are  with  other  power  marketers. Power  marketers  normally  do  not  attempt  to  be  an electric utility's all-requirements supplier.
Information  published  this  year  in  the  Electric  Sales and  Revenue   reflects   the   implementation   of   “retail wheeling” programs designed by the State legislatures and   regulatory   agencies   as   authorized   under   the EPACT.  In  2000,  several  States  reacted  to  provisions in   EPACT   allowing   “retail   wheeling”   with   States forming  programs  where  a  number  of  retail  electric consumers    could    select    their    suppliers.    Power marketers,  as  well  as  marketing  affiliates  of  electric utilities, were active participants in those programs.
As of the time of publication of the Electric Sales and Revenue 2000,  about  70  power  marketers  and  8  tradi- tional  electric  utilities  reported  sales  to  ultimate  con- sumers in deregulated markets in 17 States. Tables C1 through  C4  show  that  power  marketers  and  electric utilities  in  Pennsylvania  had  the  largest  volume  of unregulated  retail  sales,  primarily  to  commercial  and industrial consumers. However, nearly 8 percent of all residential  customers  in  Pennsylvania  selected  a  com- petitive supplier in 2000.
Major  programs  were  underway  in  2000  in  several States including California, Delaware, Illinois, Maine, Maryland,   Massachusetts,   Michigan,   Montana,   New Hampshire,   New   Jersey,   New   York,   Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, and Washington.
Data   reported   to   the   Energy   Information   Adminis- tration  (EIA)  on  the  Form  EIA-861  by  participants should   be   viewed   in   the   context   of   the   respective program. Customers   choose   alternate   suppliers   because   they gain    savings    over    their    traditional    utility's    rate. However,   other   customers   remain   with   their   tradi- tional  supplier  because  ESPs  cannot  beat  every  price offered  by  the  traditional  utility.  Statistical  data  gen- erated  by  the  electricity  consumption  and  billings,  for customers  who  did  not  choose  an  alternate  supplier, are  recorded  by  the  local  utility  and  submitted  to  the EIA.   Statistical   data   generated   by   "shopping"   cus- tomers  are  recorded  by  the  ESP  and  submitted  to  the EIA.    For    the    "shopping"    customers,    the    related delivery  services  revenue  are  submitted  to  the  EIA  by the    distribution    company    for    customers    in    their service   area   regardless   of   the   ESP   providing   the power. Because a customer at the high end of rates for electric  power  would  naturally  be  more  inclined  to switch  suppliers,  and  customers  at  the  low  end  would be  more  likely  to  remain  with  their  traditional  sup- plier,  a  distillation  process  may  sometimes  result  in the  traditional  utility  retaining  a  slightly  higher  ratio of low-rate consumers, than competing ESPs.
Analysts  should  also  be  aware  that  unbundled  cus- tomers  appear  only  in  States  that  opened  markets  to competition,  and  that  these  States  deregulated  their markets  precisely  because  customers  in  those  States
column33:
(i.e.,  California,  Pennsylvania,  and  New  York)  paid more  for  electricity  than  customers  in  other  States. Moreover,    even    within    States    that    opened    their markets,   customers   who   pay   the   highest   rates   are more likely to switch suppliers, than customers paying lower rates.
It  should  be  further  noted  that  specific  data  on  indi- vidual  customers'  level  of  service  (i.e.,  higher  cost "green" power, versus fossil-fuel, or firm versus inter- ruptible)  or  load  characteristics  (demand  and  energy consumption patterns) are not collected. Also, data are State-level  averages  and  do  not  address  whether  spe- cific  customers,  in  specific  utility  service  territories, paid more, or less than the State average.
The  EIA  notes  differences  in  the  data  between  ESPs reporting    sales    activity    and    distribution    utilities reporting delivery services. Energy analysts should be well  informed  regarding  certain  aspects  of  the  data collected  for  this  publication.  For  instance,  most  tra- ditional  distribution  utility  (TDU)  respondents  have reported  data  to  the  EIA  or  predecessor  agencies  for decades,   and   on   the   Form   EIA-861   for   17   years. Moreover, the costs of developing effective regulatory reporting  systems  used  by  most  delivery  respondents

Thus, these  respondents  have  evolved  accounting  and  other information  management  systems  over  the  years  that have  enabled  them  to  provide  high-quality  data  to  the EIA.  However,  new  industry  participants,  especially retail   ESPs   first   appearing   in   the   mid-'90s,   have shown   an   organizational   volatility   with   regard   to market  entry,  affiliate  creation,  and  market  departure. Many  of  these  recent  industry  participants  have  had limited   opportunity   to   develop   data   tracking   and reporting systems similar to those of the long-standing traditional energy suppliers.
For the purposes of this publication, and for several of the  reasons  stated  above,  the  EIA  believes  the  data reported  by  the  TDUs  is  generally  more  complete  and reliable  than  the  data  submitted  by  ESPs  at  the  State and   sector   level. Many   challenges   presented   themselves   to administrative  and  billing  staff  at  affected  utilities. For  instance,  in  some  States  with  "retail  wheeling" programs,  large  industrial  customers  could  select  one alternate  supplier  for  part  of  their  load,  another  alter- nate  supplier  for  another  portion,  and  the  regulated utility  for  the  balance. Source of Data
The  Electric  Sales  and  Revenue  (ESR)  is  prepared  by the  Electric  Power  Division;  Office  of  Coal,  Nuclear, Electric  and  Alternate  Fuels  (CNEAF);  Energy  Infor- mation   Administration   (EIA);   U.S.   Department   of Energy.  Data  published  in  the ESR  are  compiled  from the    EIA    statistical    survey    using    Form    EIA-861, “Annual  Electric  Utility  Report.”  A  brief  summary  of the form is presented below.
Form EIA-861
The  Form  EIA-861  is  a  mandatory  annual  census  of electric  utilities  in  the  United  States.  The  survey  is used   to   collect   information   on   power   production, sales,  delivery  services  in  restructured  markets,  and demand-side-management   data   from   approximately 3,300  electric  utilities.  The  collected  data  are  used  to maintain  and  update  EIA's  electric  utility  frame  data- base.   This   database   enables   analysts   to   respond   to queries  from  the  Executive  Branch,  Congress,  other public agencies, and the general public. Data from the Form  EIA-861  also  appear  in  other  EIA  publications: Electric   Power   Monthly,   Electric   Power   Annual, Volume  I,  Electric  Power  Annual,  Volume  II,  Finan- cial  Statistics  of  Major  U.S.  Publicly  Owned  Electric Utilities,  Monthly  Energy  Review,  and  Annual  Energy Review, and Annual Energy Outlook, and U.S. Electric Utility    Demand-Side    Management.    These    reports present   aggregate   totals   for   electric   utilities   at   the national, regional, and/or State levels.
Instrument  and  Design  History.    Use  of  the  Form EIA-861 was begun in January 1985 to collect data as of  year-end  1984.  The  Federal  Energy  Administration Act  of  1974  (Public  Law  93-275)  defines  the  legisla- tive authority to collect these data.
Data  Processing.    The  Form  EIA-861  is  mailed  to the respondents at year end to collect data for the cal- endar year. The completed forms are to be returned to the  EIA  by  April  30.  The  data  are  entered  into  an interactive   on-line   system.   Internal   edit   checks   are performed to verify that current data total consistently across   and   between   schedules,   and   are   comparable with  data  reported  the  previous  year.  Edit  checks  are also  performed  to  compare  data  reported  on  the  Form
EIA-861   with   similar   data   reported   on   the   Form

EIA-826, “Monthly Electric Utility Sales and Revenue with   State   Distributions,"   Form   EIA-412,   "Annual Report  of  Public  Electric  Utilities,”  and  the  Federal Energy   Regulatory   Commission   Form   1,   “Annual Report   of   Major   Electric   Utilities,   Licensees,   and Others.”  Respondents  are  contacted  by  telephone  to obtain   clarification   of   reported   data   or   to   obtain missing data.
The  Form  EIA-861  totals  shown  in  this  publication differ  somewhat  from  the  sum  of  the  monthly  Form EIA-826   data   for   sales   published   in   the   Electric Power  Monthly  and  in  issues  of  the  Electric  Power Annual  prior  to  1988.  Both  forms  use  sectorial  classi- fications    (residential,    commercial,    industrial,    and other)  based  on  the  classification  of  consumers  by  the electric  utilities.  At  the  national  level,  totals  from  the Form  EIA-861  and  Form  EIA-826  correspond  closely (within 1 percent) for all end-use sectors. Some larger differences  appear  at  the  State  level,  however,  partic- ularly for Tennessee, due to an inconsistency between the  two  forms  in  the  classification  of  commercial  and and industrial data.
Differences   between   the   Form   EIA-861   and   Form EIA-826 totals can also result from the Form EIA-826 sampling  procedure  and/or  from  nonsampling  error  in either   data   collection.   One   source   of   nonsampling error  in  the  Form  EIA-826  stems  from  the  practice  of filing  estimates  for  monthly  sales  and  revenue  when actual figures are not yet available. Although respond- ents   are   instructed   to   file   revisions,   they   do   not always  do  so.  The  respondents  are  also  instructed  to review  the  sum  of  their  EIA-826  monthly  data  at  the end  of  the  reporting  year  to  ensure  consistency  with Form EIA-861 annual data. Survey analysts at the EIA compare  these  data  series  and  attempt  to  resolve  any differences.  Nevertheless,  some  reporting  differences remain.
Electric   revenue   and   sales   data   are   rounded   and reported  by  electric  utilities  in  thousand  dollars  and thousand   kilowatthours.   For   this   publication,   the average  revenue  per  unit  of  electricity  sold  is  calcu- lated  by  dividing  electric  revenue  from  sales  to  ulti- mate    consumers    by    the    corresponding    sales    of electricity. Base  Bill:    A  charge  calculated  by  taking  the  rate from    the    appropriate    electric    rate    schedule    and applying it to the level of consumption.
Base Rate:   A fixed per-kilowatthour charge for elec- tricity  consumed  that  is  independent  of  other  charges and/or adjustments.
Block Rate Schedule:   An electric rate schedule with a   provision   for   charging   a   different   unit   cost   for various   increasing   blocks   of   demand   or   energy. Usually   a   reduced   price   is   charged   on   succeeding blocks.
Bundled  Consumers:    Consumers  provided  full  elec- tric  service  (energy  and  delivery)  by  a  single  utility entity (see unbundled).
Census  Divisions:    The  nine  geographic  divisions  of the  United  States  established  by  the  Bureau  of  the Census,  U.S.  Department  of  Commerce,  for  statistical analysis.  The  boundaries  of  Census  divisions  coincide with  State  boundaries.  The  Pacific  Division  is  subdi- vided into the Pacific Contiguous and Pacific Noncon- tiguous areas.
Classes  of  Service:    Groups  of  consumers  identified on  the  basis  of  shared  characteristics  for  the  purpose of  setting  common  rates  for  electric  service.  These groups  are  usually  residential,  commercial,  industrial and other.
Class   Rate   Schedule:     An   electric   rate   schedule applicable to one or more specified classes of service, groups of businesses, or customer uses.
Commercial  Sector:    The  commercial  sector  is  gen- erally   defined   as   nonmanufacturing   business   estab- lishments,    including    hotels,    motels,    restaurants, wholesale  businesses,  retail  stores,  and  health,  social, and   educational   institutions.   Electric   utilities   may classify  commercial  service  as  service  that  includes all  consumers  whose  demand  or  annual  use  exceeds some  specified  limit.  The  limit  may  be  set  by  the utility  based  on  the  rate  schedule  of  the  utility.  If certain  consumers  (e.g.,  farms  or  irrigation  projects) cannot   be   identified   as   residential,   commercial,   or industrial,  they  should  be  classified  with  the  group they   most   closely   resemble.   If   there   is   no   rate schedule  distinction,  utilities  may  define  commercial consumers   as   those   having   a   demand   of   less   than 1,000 kilowatts.
column33:
Consumer  Charge:    An  amount  charged  periodically to  a  consumer  for  such  utility  costs  as  billing  and meter  reading,  without  regard  to  demand  or  energy consumption.
Cooperative   Electric   Utility:     A   group   organized under  the  law  into  a  utility  company  that  will  gen- erate,  transmit,  and/or  distribute  supplies  of  electric energy   to   a   specified   area   not   being   serviced   by another  utility.  Such  ventures  are  generally  exempt from the Federal income tax laws. Most electric coop- eratives   have   initially   been   financed   by   the   Rural Utilities Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture.
Cost  of  Service:    A  ratemaking  concept  used  for  the design  and  development  of  rate  schedules  to  ensure that  the  filed  rate  schedules  recover  only  the  cost  of providing  the  electric  service  at  issue.  These  costs include  operating  and  maintenance  expenses,  depreci- ation   and   amortization   expenses,   and   income   and other  taxes  that  the  regulatory  agency  finds  just  and reasonable    to    include    in    costs    considered    for ratemaking.  In  addition,  privately  owned  utilities  may include  in  the  cost  of  service  an  allowance  for  return on  capital  (usually  computed  by  applying  a  rate  of return  to  the  rate  base).  This  concept  represents  an effort  to  equate  the  costs  incurred  by  the  utility  with the  revenue  received  for  the  service  provided  to  each of the consumer classes.
Demand   (Electric):     The   rate   at   which   electric energy   is   delivered   to   or   by   a   system,   part   of   a system,  or  piece  of  equipment,  at  a  given  instant  or averaged over any designated period of time.
Demand  Charge:    The  portion  of  the  consumer's  bill for  electric  service  that  is  based  on  the  consumer's maximum electric capacity usage.
Economy  of  Scale:    The  principle  that  larger  pro- duction  facilities  have  lower  unit  costs  than  smaller facilities.
Electric  Power  Industry:    The  privately,  publicly, federally,  and  cooperatively  owned  electric  utilities and nonutilities of the United States taken as a whole. Includes  all  electric  systems  serving  the  public:  regu- lated    investor-owned    electric    utility    companies; Federal  power  projects;  State,  municipal,  and  other government-owned  systems,  including  electric  public utility districts; electric cooperatives, including gener- ation and transmission entities; and nonutilites.

Electric  Rate:    The  price  set  for  a  specified  amount of  electricity  in  an  electric  rate  schedule  or  sales  con- tract.

Electric   utilities   include   privately   owned,   publicly owned,  cooperatively  owned,  and  government-owned (municipals,   Federal   agencies,   State   projects,   and public power districts) systems.
Energy:   The capacity for doing work as measured by the  capability  of  doing  work  (potential  energy)  or  the conversion    of    this    capability    to    motion    (kinetic energy).  Energy  has  several  forms,  some  of  which  are easily convertible and can be changed to another form useful   for   work.   Most   of   the   world's   convertible energy   comes   from   fossil   fuels   that   are   burned   to produce heat that is then used as a transfer medium to mechanical   or   other   means   in   order   to   accomplish tasks.    Electrical    energy    is    usually    measured    in kilowatthours,  while  heat  energy  is  usually  measured in British thermal units.
Energy   Information   Administration   (EIA):     An independent   agency   within   the   U.S.   Department   of Energy  that  develops  surveys,  collects  energy  data, and  produces  analyses  of  energy  issues  and  models  to project    future    developments.    The    agency    must respond   to   requests   of   Congress,   other   elements within   the   Department   of   Energy,   Federal   Energy Regulatory  Commission,  the  Executive  Branch,  and its own independent needs, and must assist the general public   and   other   interest   groups   without   taking   a policy position.
Federal  Energy  Regulatory  Commission  (FERC): A   quasi-independent   regulatory   agency   within   the Department  of  Energy  having  jurisdiction  over  inter- state  electricity  sales,  wholesale  electric  rates,  hydro- electric   licensing,   natural   gas   pricing,   oil   pipeline rates, and gas pipeline certification.
Flat   and   Meter   Rate   Schedule:     An   electric   rate schedule  consisting  of  two  components,  the  first  of which  is  a  service  charge,  and  the  second,  a  price  for the energy consumed.
Flat   Demand   Rate   Schedule:     An   electric   rate schedule  based  on  billing  demand  that  provides  no charge for energy.
Gigawatt (GW):   One billion watts.
Gigawatthour (GWh):   One billion watthours.
Industrial  Sector:    The  industrial  sector  is  generally defined    as    including    manufacturing,    construction, mining,   agriculture,   fishing,   and   forestry   establish-
column33:
ments  under  Standard  Industrial  Classification  (SIC) codes  01  through  39.  The  utility  may  classify  indus- trial  service  using  the  SIC  codes,  or  based  on  demand or  annual  usage  exceeding  some  specified  limit.  The limit  may  be  set  by  the  utility  based  on  its  own  rate schedule.   Sales   to   consumers   (i.e.,   farms   and   irri- gation)  that  the  utility  has  no  system  for  separating into  residential,  commercial,  and  industrial  classifica- tions  should  be  classified  based  on  the  schedule  they most closely resemble. If there is no rate schedule dis- tinction,  utilities  may  define  industrial  consumers  as those  having  a  demand  equal  to  or  greater  than  1,000 kilowatts.
Interdepartmental  Sales:    Includes  amounts  charged by  the  electric  department  at  tariff  or  other  specified rates   for   electricity   supplied   by   it   to   other   utility departments.
Investor-Owned  Electric  Utility:    A  class  of  utility that  is  investor-owned  and  organized  as  a  tax-paying business, usually financed by the sales of securities in the capital market.
Kilowatt (kW):   One thousand watts.
Kilowatthour (kWh):   One thousand watthours.
Megawatt (MW):   One million watts.
Megawatthour (MWh):   One million watthours.
Other  Sector:    Electricity  supplied  to  public  street and  highway  lighting,  other  service  to  public  authori- ties,  service  to  railroads  and  and  railways,  and  inter- departmental service.
Power  (Electrical):    An  electric  unit  of  power  called a  voltampere  is  equal  to  the  product  of  1  volt  and  1 ampere.   This   is   equivalent   to   1   watt   for   a   direct current  system,  and  a  unit  of  apparent  power  is  sepa- rated  into  real  and  reactive  power.  Real  power  is  the work-producing  part  of  apparent  power  that  measures the  rate  of  supply  of  energy  and  is  denoted  as  kilo- watts  (kW).  Reactive  power  is  the  portion  of  apparent power that does no work and is referred to as kilovars; this  type  of  power  must  be  supplied  to  most  types  of magnetic  equipment,  such  as  motors,  and  is  supplied by     generator     or     by     electrostatic     equipment. Voltamperes  are  usually  divided  by  1,000  and  called kilovoltamperes   (kVA).   Energy   is   denoted   by   the product  of  real  power  and  the  length  of  time  utilized; this product is expressed as kilowatthours.
Power   Marketers:     Business   entities   engaged   in buying,   selling,   and   marketing   electricity.   Power marketers  do  not  ususally  own  generating  or  trans- mission   facilities.   Power   marketers,   as   opposed   to Power  Brokers,  take  ownership  of  the  electricity  and are  involved  in  interstate  trade.  These  entities  must file  with  the  Federal  Energy  Regulatory  Commission for approval of rate tariffs.
Public  Authorities:    Electricity  supplied  to  munici- palities  or  divisions  or  agencies  of  State  and  Federal governments, usually under special contracts or agree- ments that are applicable only to public authorities.

Public Street and Highway Lighting Service:   Elec- tricity  supplied  and  services  rendered  for  the  purpose of  lighting  streets,  highways,  parks,  and  other  public places;  or  for  traffic  or  other  signal  system  service, for  municipalities,  or  other  divisions  or  agencies  of State or Federal governments.
Publicly  Owned  Electric  Utility:    A  class  of  utility that   includes   those   utilities   operated   by   munici- palities,  political  subdivisions,  utility  or  power  dis- tricts, and State and Federal power agencies.
Railroad  and  Railway  Electric  Service:    Electricity supplied  to  railroads  and  interurban  and  street  rail- ways,  for  general  railroad  use,  including  the  propul- sion  of  cars  or  locomotives,  where  such  electricity  is supplied under separate and distinct rate schedules.
Rate   Base:     The   value   of   property   upon   which   a utility is permitted to earn a specified rate of return as established  by  a  regulatory  authority.  The  rate  base generally  represents  the  value  of  property  used  by  the utility  in  providing  service  and  may  be  calculated  by any  one  or  a  combination  of  the  following  accounting methods:  fair  value,  prudent  investment,  reproduction cost,  or  original  cost.  Depending  on  which  method  is used,  the  rate  base  includes  cash,  working  capital, materials  and  supplies,  and  deductions  for  accumu- lated  provisions  for  depreciation,  contributions  in  aid of  construction,  customer  advances  for  construction, accumulated  deferred  income  taxes,  and  accumulated deferred investment tax credits.
Residential  Sector:    The  residential  sector  includes private   homes,   including   apartment   buildings,   that consume   energy   primarily   for   space   heating,   water heating,    air    conditioning,    lighting,    refrigeration, cooking,  and  clothes  drying.  The  classification  of  an individual  consumer's  account,  where  the  use  is  both residential and commercial, is based on principal use.
Retail:    Sales  covering  electrical  energy  supplied  for residential,  commercial,  and  industrial  end-use  pur- poses.  Other  small  classes,  such  as  agriculture  and street lighting, also are included in this category.
Rural  Electrification  Administration  (REA):    See Rural Utilities Service (RUS).
Rural  Utilities  Service  (RUS)  (formerly  the  Rural Electrification  Administration):    A  lending  agency of   the   U.S.   Department   of   Agriculture,   the   RUS makes  self-liquidating  loans  to  qualified  borrowers  to finance  electric  and  telephone  service  to  rural  areas.
column33:
The  RUS  also  finances  the  construction  and  operation of  generating  plants,  electric  transmission  and  distrib- ution lines, or systems for the furnishing of initial and continued   adequate   electric   services   to   persons   in rural areas not receiving central station service.
Sales:    The  amount  of  kilowatthours  sold  in  a  given period  of  time;  usually  grouped  by  classes  of  service, such  as  residential,  commercial,  industrial,  and  other. Other    sales    include    sales    for    public    street    and highway  lighting,  sales  to  public  authorities,  sales  to railroads and railways, and interdepartmental sales.
Schedule:    A  statement  of  the  pricing  format  of  elec- tricity   and   the   terms   and   conditions   governing   its applications.
Seasonal  Rates:    Different  seasons  of  the  year  are structured  into  an  electric  rate  schedule  whereby  an electric  utility  provides  service  to  consumers  at  dif- ferent  rates.  The  electric  rate  schedule  usually  takes into   account   demand   based   on   weather   and   other factors.
Special  Contract  Rate  Schedule:    An  electric  rate schedule  for  an  electric  service  agreement  between  a utility and another party in addition to, or independent of, any standard rate schedule.
Special   Purpose   Rate   Schedule:     An   electric   rate schedule  limited  in  its  application  to  some  particular purpose or process within one, or more than one, type of industry or business.
Tariff:    A  published  volume  of  rate  schedules  and general terms and conditions under which a product or service will be supplied.
Time-of-Day  Rate:    The  rate  charged  by  an  electric utility for service to various classes of customers. The rate   reflects   the   different   costs   of   providing   the service at different times of the day.
Unbundled Consumers:   Consumers provided energy and  delivery  electric  service  by  separate  utility  enti- ties.
Watt:     The   electrical   unit   of   power.   The   rate   of energy  transfer  equivalent  to  1  ampere  flowing  under a pressure of 1 volt at unity power factor.
Watthour    (Wh):      An    electrical    energy    unit    of measure equal to 1 watt of power supplied to, or taken from, an electric circuit steadily for 1 hour.
